Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: My phone buzzed again, the screen lighting up with another message from Mom. She wanted to know if I’d eaten lunch, if I was wearing my jacket, if I’d remembered to call Auntie about her birthday. I’d always made it a point to reply quickly, to keep our daily conversations going—she said it made her feel close, especially since Dad passed. But right now, I was kneeling on the splintered boards of Mrs. Lee’s deck, tools scattered around me, sweat trickling down my back. She stood nearby, anxious, watching every move. The deck was worse than I’d thought; some beams needed replacing, and she wanted it done before her family barbecue tomorrow. My phone buzzed again. I could almost hear Mom’s worried voice in my head, but Mrs. Lee’s eyes were on me, expecting me to focus, to fix her deck before the sun set. I stared at my phone, torn between the comfort of my mother’s expectations and the pressing demands of my work, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which to answer first.
